text:
We need to strengthen and expand our regulations around coal pollution to protect human health and slow climate damage. If regulation hastens our migration to renewable and sustainable energy sources, all the better. There is no valid economic argument for gutting these regulations and compelling urgency to stop environmental degradation.

Specifically:
Coal mining destroys ecosystems, releases toxic levels of minerals and gases into our water and air (including methane), and exposes people to coal dust and toxins.
Coal is the largest source of climate-changing CO2 pollution.
Coal burning releases millions of tons of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides, creating acid rain and smog.
Coal burning yields particulate matter pollution, which creates air pollution and respiratory ailments.
Coal burning releases mercury, which infiltrates the food chain and attacks the human nervous system.
Coal burning creates millions of tons of waste containing toxic levels of heavy metals, much of which end up in landfills.

text: It is important that we keep all current clean air and water regulations. As a resident of Los Angeles, my family and I have benefitted from significant smog reductions thanks to clean air mandates which have cleaned up the exhaust coming from cars on the road and pollution coming from businesses and homes in the region. I have asthma and it's important to me, especially during the warm summer months where there are still numerous dirty air days, that we continue to have regulations which limit what we are allowed to emit into our air and water. And, in a region where clean water is at a premium, we need to make sure there is enough clean water accessible to residents whatever their income can afford. As we have seen in Flint, without proper testing and regulation, water quality can go unchecked and will continue to be problematic with the increased use of water in natural gas extraction and the unfortunate spills we have seen all over the country into creeks and rivers which serve as primary sources of drinking water for most Americans.

text: It is likely that the proposed cuts to the EPA will not only inhibit EPA's ability to regulate under their current established mandates, but also their ability to conduct future assessments. Specifically, according the the court case Michigan vs EPA, the EPA will likely have to conduct many more cost/benefit analysis in order to determine the value of proposed regulations. A reduction in the EPA budget will reduce their ability to complete these assessments effectively. The failure to account for the externalities of proposed industrial activities on human health and economic activity, will harm our nation for decades to come. The EPA must have the funding to sufficiently assess the negative externalities that result from economic decisions such that we can incorporate them into our decision making as a nation in terms of future investments.

text:
Dear EPA -

You should not change the existing regulations that protect clean air, clean water and land. Rolling back the good efforts that the EPA has already completed on behalf of human health and ecological health is non sensical.

The current effort by President Trump and the EPA's Scott Pruitt are foolhardy and do not represent clear thinking on behalf of the American public.

Past Presidents, both Republican and Democrat, have enacted multiple laws to protect the our air, water and land from pollution. It is simply a foolhardy and easy scapegoat to blame "regulation" for the inability of old industries to gain back what has been long in coming. There is no reason to have human health put in jeopardy by coal pollution, and other pollutants. People and wildlife need clean air and water, and rolling back existing regulations will reduce protection for people and wildlife.

Gaining a few cents on the dollar in profit is no excuse to risk people's lives. Thanks for your consideration.

Jim Balmer
Des Moines, Iowa

text:
The health of our environment is directly related to the health of our people, our planet, our future. Regulations are necessary to ensure that the health of the people is put above any commercial interests. It has been proven time and again that businesses do not do a good job of regulating themselves (look at Louisiana - loose on regulations, the most polluted state in the US. There's a corridor known as "Cancer Alley" due to all the industrial contamination). The EPA should be using the latest science to tweak, target, and expand regulations, but there certainly should not be a wide rollback of regulations. There is little evidence to support the claim that environmental regulations hurt the economy or cost jobs - but even if they did cost jobs in the short term, isn't it worth it for the future of our planet? Environmental damage is long-lasting and will cost money in health care, premature deaths, lost productive years. Instead of rolling back regulations to boost business, we should be looking for innovative new business opportunities that don't put our planet in peril.

We are all connected, and what happens upriver flows downriver; what happens upwind moves downwind; what happens on one coast flows across ocean currents to another continent. The federal government, and indeed multilateral institutions, must play a role because environmental polluters do not know state or national boundaries. Every single person on this planet has the right to breathe clean air that won't give them asthma, drink water that will not give them heavy metal poisoning, go to work every day at a job that won't give them cancer. This is the job of the EPA and the point of regulations - to ensure that they can do all of those things.

text: The cutbacks, as proposed, benefit virtually no one but larger corporations and not the American public at large. text:
The proposed rule suggests that regulations should be evaluated based on whether they:
"(i) Eliminate jobs, or inhibit job creation;
(ii) are outdated, unnecessary, or ineffective;
(iii) impose costs that exceed benefits;
(iv) create a serious inconsistency or otherwise interfere with regulatory reform initiatives and policies;
(v) are inconsistent with the requirements of section 515 of the Treasury and General Government Appropriates Act, 2001 (44 U.S.C. 3516 note), or the guidance issued pursuant to that provision in particular those regulations that rely in whole or in part on data, information, or methods that are not publicly available or that are insufficiently transparent to meet the standard of reproducibility; or
(vi) derive from or implement Executive Orders or other Presidential directives that have been subsequently rescinded or substantially modified.""

Nowhere in that list is an evaluation as to whether the regulations do what they're supposed to do - protect citizens and the environment from hazards created by industry and by society. That should be the standard for regulations. Whether or not they interfere with someone's profit is irrelevant in this context.

When possible, support your comment with substantive data, facts, and/or expert opinions." I believe these regulations were developed using sound science, substantive data, facts, and expert opinions. Clean air and water are not an inconvenience for corporations, they are an investment in the future of our country and protection for our citizens. I see no reason why the carefully developed regulations should be rolled back and the administration has provided zero rationale. The planet needs our leadership on environmental protections, including investments in renewable energy and clean power. text:
Dear EPA Regulatory Reform Task Force members:

Please convey the following three points to Administrator Scott Pruitt.

1. EPA regulation of clean air is both effective and desired by a majority of the American people. We do not have significant problems with acid rain anymore because of EPA regulation of sulfur dioxide. We used to have a big, growing hole in the ozone layer, until the EPA regulated certain aerosols. The EPA can and must do the same with greenhouse gas emissions. According to research from Jon Krosnick at Stanford Public Opinion on Climate Change, a majority of Americans support government regulation on this issue and are willing to pay more for goods in exchange for a sustainable environment. This research is consistently confirmed in polls by The Washington Post/ABC News, Duke University, Quinnipiac, and Gallup, to name just a few.

2. A small number of big polluters with deep pockets may be opposed to regulation, but trade associations representing over 60,000 small business owners (of which I am one) are vocally opposing efforts to curb greenhouse gas regulations. Many in the business community see how thoughtful, necessary regulation spurs innovation and research, generating jobs and profits and positioning US companies to be more competitive in the global marketplace. http://www.biologicaldiversity.org/programs/climate_law_institute/global_warming_litigation/clean_air_act/pdfs/American_Business_for_Clean_Energy_2010.pdf

3. Individual liberty is at stake. The states that generate the most pollution also pollute states around them and contribute to global warming for everyone. Big companies that pollute the air and water do the same. Both resist reasonable regulation because they want, in essence, a handout. That is, they want to profit while passing off the costs of dealing with environmental pollution to their neighbors and to the rest of the inhabitants of the planet.

As a taxpayer, an involved, conscientious citizen, a business owner, and a human being who needs to breathe clean air in a stable climate -- and as a parent who wants the same for my children and their children -- I am asking you to communicate to the Administrator of the EPA that I do not want a repeal or relaxation of existing regulations. Instead, I want thoughtful, vigorous enforcement of current EPA regulations and intelligent, well-informed implementation of new regulations that are needed to slow the course of climate change. Greed and denial must not be allowed to bring us to ruin.

Sincerely,
Kelly Priest

docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
EPA regulations should not be reduced, they should be strengthened and properly enforced. Especially, attention should continue to be paid to carbon emissions and other greenhouse gasses in an effort to combat climate change. And please know that the American people value clean air and water just as much as a strong economy. You must offer both!

Of specific concern to me are the following sections:

"iii) impose costs that exceed benefits;"

It is impossible to quantify the health benefits of clean air, water, and mitigating climate change relative to financial expenditure.

"(iv) create a serious inconsistency or otherwise interfere with regulatory reform initiatives and policies;"

This is too broad and subjective, allowing the rejection of regulations at the whim of the Executive branch.

"(v) are inconsistent with the requirements of section 515 of the Treasury and General Government Appropriates Act, 2001 (44 U.S.C. 3516 note), or the guidance issued pursuant to that provision in particular those regulations that rely in whole or in part on data, information, or methods that are not publicly available or that are insufficiently transparent to meet the standard of reproducibility;"

"Publicly available" should not be interpreted to mean only free and/or open access information. All scholarly research that has been published, even in for-fee journals, should be included in EPA decision making.

Thank you and God Bless America,
Stephen Duncan

text:
Regulations stemming from the Clean Power Plan and the Clean Air Act are not outdated or ineffective. Scientific evidence of the need for these regulations is stronger today than when the rules were put into place. Out citizens deserve government protection from radiation and particulate matter that create human health risks and disease. Cost benefit ratios should take into account long term medical costs, loss of ability to work, and related poverty as the real costs for the nation. Loss of property values in affected areas is another real cost of damage to local environments.

Coal jobs will never outnumber jobs in clean energy, which is the future for our country and for the world. Reversing and eliminating environmental and health protections will endanger the health of our citizens through increased water, ground, and air pollution. One only has to look at the health consequences that long term employment in coal mines has caused for its workers, and reduced regulations will endanger the communities near the mines as well as anyone downstream from local water sources. The same consequences will happen from pipelines such as the Keystone and the North Dakota Access Pipeline. text:

Please do not adopt this rule.

We support the IPA's Citizen Petition requesting a change to the way that the amount of probiotic ingredients are required to be declared on the labels of dietary supplements in the United States.  Specifically, we agree that FDA should amend 21 CFR 101.36 to require that the quantitative amount of probiotic ingredients in dietary supplements be declared in terms of colony forming units (CFUs) instead of by weight."  Probiotics are a unique category of dietary ingredients, and the weight of probiotics in a dietary supplement is not relevant information for consumers since only live, active probiotics can confer a health benefit.   Requiring probiotics to be declared in terms of CFUs would be consistent with international standards, FDA practice in other contexts (e.g. GRAS Petitions), how they are discussed in the scientific literature, and would provide useful information to consumers to make informed choices.

Dear FDA:
I join with the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express my concern of the FDA requirement of packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars." This will confuse food consumers.

If this label is implemented at the commercial beekeeping level it will begin the misinformation to food consumers that sugar is added to honey. Eventually, it will create confusion across the honey industry and mislead the consumer about a natural product.

As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."

If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.

I realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and would therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label. However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.

I share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice and promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey.
As a beekeeper I encourage the FDA to consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."

Why would you want a label falsely claiming that sugar has been "added"? I don't add sugar to the honey I harvest, so if I have to add this to my labels this now become misleading to the public. Not a good idea.

Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).

I support this regulation. As organic foods and products have become more popular, producers have obtained significant benefits from increased demand. However, this increase in demand for organic products has created new incentives for irresponsible and dishonest producers to cut corners in the production process. It is essential that the organic integrity of industry products is protected through reasonable and measured regulation. These changes also protects honest producers from corrupt competitors that would tarnish the industry's reputation for their own short term benefits. When shown the difference between true-organic and nonorganic products, consumers immediately realize the health and happiness benefits they provide. Consumers have come to expect high quality organic products and we must protect that standard.

My note of caution to the industry would be to ensure that input from producers in constantly measured. The industry should work hand-in-hand with regulators to protect the integrity of organic products. Despite the good will that should exist between the industry and regulators, it is essential that the USDA recognize the need for flexibility. Regulation of industries across our economy is often slow to change and frequently fails to keep up with changing dynamics. This cannot be the case with the organic market. USDA should implement systems to monitor and proactively adapt to the industry needs and demands. This process should be transparent with input from stakeholders at every step. After all, these systems are being adopted to protect honest producers.

With that, I commend the work of USDA and industry partners in their joint efforts to protect organic. Thank you.

It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

We should get rid of these government agencies so we don't have to use taxpayer to fund organic research.
Different industries should fund their own organic research so we don't have to use our own taxpayer money for that research.

Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

docAbstract: NOAA proposes to designate approximately 52 square miles of waters encompassing and surrounding Maryland’s Mallows Bay as the Mallows Bay – Potomac River National Marine Sanctuary (MPNMS or sanctuary). NOAA also proposes regulations to implement the sanctuary designation and establish the sanctuary’s terms of designation to protect historical, archeological, and cultural resources of national significance. A draft environmental impact statement (DEIS) and draft management plan have also been prepared for this proposed action.

docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

text: Honey has no added sugar and should not be labeled as such.  It is a pure substance made wholely by honeybees.

I am perplexed why anyone would think this is a good idea. I join with the Honey and Pollination Center, Robert Mondavi Institute, UC Davis, the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express concern of the FDA requirement for packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars."
This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars."
Not only is this confusing for consumers, it is also incorrect. There are no added sugars in pure honey. Honey is a totally natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.

Dear FDA,

As a consumer, I am concerned about the new legislation proposed for nutrition labels as it pertains to pure, jarred honey. I have read that adding the line, "added sugars," to the labeling requirements is intended to differentiate between healthy and "empty" calories, and I agree that this is a good thing to communicate. If this was the differentiation that I as a consumer would see, I would be 100% for it.

Unfortunately, the label information, as currently written, does not communicate this. It communicates to the consumer that the beekeeping and honey industry is adding sugars to our honey, when in fact it is a pure and whole food that has not been altered in any way. As there have been numerous accounts recently of adulterated honey entering the US market, and selling adulterated honey is illegal, forcing beekeepers to say that they have added sugars to their honey (making it adulterated), when they have not, will be bad for both consumers and beekeepers. The end result will be further confusion from the nutrition label, rather than clarification.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

The proposed modifications considered for the labeling of pure honey, which I and many other vendors market, would be completely unnecessary. Honey is naturally occurring sugar. It has no "added sugar" and to even place that entry on the label would be confusing to consumers. Also there is no need for an "expiration date" as pure honey does not spoil or become unusable. I join with other honey vendors to strongly oppose the requirement for either of these items to be required on honey labeling. They are unnecessary and misleading.

We don't need or want organic check off it will only help the middle man as in the conventional farming. Big corporations are wanting to take charge for big profit on our backs. So don't let the money take your ear listen to the people.

I am concerned about the general applicability of the study. Specifically, that the schools selected for this study likely have some form of sex education that might play a factor in determining whether a particular student will engage in such risky behavior. While students from the same school or that have the same type of sex education may share similar results, whether the results may be extrapolated to high risk students in areas that emphasize abstinence over contraception is a question, and perhaps a study is needed in geographically and educationally diverse populations.

Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

I think the delay will be good.This additional delay will allow OSHA officials the opportunity for further review and consideration of the new regulations. Workers in industries where beryllium is present may be exposed to beryllium by inhaling or contacting beryllium in the air or on surfaces. Inhaling or contacting beryllium can cause an immune response that results in an individual becoming sensitized to beryllium.
